title: Red Wharf Bay Walking Route

nearby.description: Benllech to Red Wharf Bay Walk

images.title: Dr Neil Clifton / Red Wharf Bay, Anglesey, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Nice view of the bay and cottages

images.title: Nigel Williams / Carpark at Eastern side of Red Wharf Bay, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Car park at Eastern side of the bay. This is a view of the beach carpark to the North of Llanddona, which also has a beach shop and public conveniences

images.title: Trish Steel [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The bay's Welsh name is Traeth Coch (Red Beach). The bay is very shallow and at low tide almost 25 square kilometres of sand is uncovered. The tide was on its way in at the time of my visit.

images.title: John S Turner / View across Red Wharf Bay, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Beach view at low tide

images.title: Paul Harrop / Castell Mawr, Red Wharf Bay, Anglesey, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Castell Mawr. Limestone rock overlooking the bay, popular with tourists and seagulls alike.

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Red Wharf Bay, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking west at high tide.

images.title: Brian Green / The Ship Inn, Red Wharf Bay, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Ship Inn. This is an olde worlde pub set in a stunning location on the shore of Red Wharf Bay (Welsh name Traeth Coch).

images.title: Keith Williamson / Red Wharf Bay, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Red Wharf Bay. Street scene in the village above the bay.

description: This walk uses part of the Anglesey Coast Path to explore this expansive sandy bay located on the east coast of Anglesey. The area is an area of outstanding natural beauty with fabulous coastal views and some lovely countryside. There's also lots of pretty pools and eroded rock formations to look out for. This walk starts at the car park at the village of Red Wharf Bay and picks up the coast path to take you around the bay. It's a good path which runs along the beach with the option of climbing into the forest around Mynydd Llwdyiarth. National Cycle Route 5 runs through the village of Pentraeth which is just south of the bay. You can cycle to the village and then head along Lon y traeth to take you down to the bay. To extend your walk you can continue along the coast path to the village of Benllech. This will take you through St David's Park. Here you can try the Benllech to Moelfre Coastal Path which takes you north along a beautiful stretch of coast. If you continue east along the coast you will soon come to Penmon Point . Here you'll find the Trwyn Du Lighthouse and great views towards Puffin Island, Great Orme and Snowdon. There's also nice pebble beaches and seals and dolphins to look out for.
county: Sir Ynys Mon - Isle of Anglesey
